awd_titl_txt: Organizing to Learn Practice: Teacher Learning in Classroom-Focused Professional Development
awd_abstract_narration:
The Discovery Research K-12 program (DRK-12) seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) by preK-12 students and teachers through research and development of innovative resources, models and tools. Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for proposed projects. 

Growing evidence about the powerful effects of skillful teaching on students' learning creates a need to for professional development that impacts teachers' actual practice. Just as other professions (e.g., nursing, social work, law) have centered practitioners' learning in "live" practice with structures that support learning in context, the project will investigate whether and how this can be accomplished in teaching. The approach uses a "live mathematics classroom" as a common text for working on practice, where participants are not only watching and discussing but are engaged in developing and learning practice. The project also explores the following variations in practice-based professional development: (1) on-site and remote participation of teachers; and (2) the addition of supplementary practice-focused professional development. The project will generate new knowledge regarding ways in which elementary teachers of mathematics can be supported to learn effective teaching practice. 

This project addresses a fundamental challenge for professional development, that is, how to support teachers to improve their practice. Teachers profit from well-designed opportunities to develop new visions for practice, learn more about students' thinking, or work on specific mathematical topics or tasks. Still, such opportunities are often insufficient to support teachers with the complexity of classroom teaching. These kinds of professional opportunities focus on critical resources for instruction but not on the details of teaching practice itself. This practice-centered professional development is situated within a summer mathematics program for fifth graders. The proposed research will explore the impact on teachers' practice, as well as on their knowledge and dispositions, from participating in these structured ways. Three studies will resolve the following three sets of questions: (1) What do teachers learn from structured participation in the class? Does their participation impact their own teaching practice, and if so, in what ways? (2) Does the setting of the peripheral participation matter? Does this form of participation impact their own teaching practice, and if so, in what ways? (3) Does the addition of professional development focused on a particular teaching practice impact teachers' own practice, and if so, in what ways? How does the addition of professional development focused on a specific instructional practice compare across the in-person and online forms of participation in terms of impact on teachers' own practice? The project will collect and analyze several types of data pre- and post-intervention, including measures of mathematical knowledge for teaching, measures of language for talking about the work of teaching and students, and skill with leading a mathematics discussion, and the mathematical quality of instruction. The project will generate new knowledge related to to organizing professional learning around supports that teachers need to learn practice as well as ways to study their learning of teaching practice.

por.por_cntn:
This project addressed a fundamental challenge for professional development––how to support teachers to improve their practice. Teachers profit from well-designed opportunities to develop new visions for practice, learn more about students’ thinking, or work on specific mathematical topics or tasks. Still, such opportunities are often insufficient to support teachers with the complexity of classroom teaching. These kinds of professional opportunities do focus on critical resources for instruction, but not on the details of practice itself. In response to critiques of many existing professional development structures, we designed a professional development to support the learning of practice by situating learning inside of live instruction (Shaughnessy et al., 2017; Garcia & Shaughnessy, 2017). The approach uses an elementary mathematics classroom as a “common text” for working on practice, where participants are not only watching and discussing a series of consecutive lessons as part of a summer mathematics program for fifth grade students, but are engaged in developing and learning practice.


The approach is designed to simultaneously support teachers’ and students’ learning. This common text of teaching and student learning creates opportunities for participants to 1) examine lesson plans and student tasks, 2) discuss the plans and tasks with the teacher of record, making adjustments together, 3) observe the enactment of the discussed lesson, including deviations from and adjustments to the planned lesson, 4) collaboratively review students’ daily work, and 5) debrief the teaching of the lesson, unpacking adjustments and deviations from the plan, the mathematics that unfolded during the lesson, and moves the teacher made to engage students in mathematics discussion. Unlike other professional development structures that situate professional development inside colleagues’ classrooms, this professional development was situated in a summer program taught by a member of our research team. 


This collaborative investigation of teaching was coupled with a discussion professional development session in the afternoon. The professional development session was designed to give teacher participants opportunities to dive more deeply into discussion leading practice. It included unpacking discussions in other classroom contexts and trying out particular parts of discussion practice.


In order to expand opportunities for teacher participation, the project offered a structure allowing a group of participants to engage remotely in the full professional development. This remote participation was not a “hybrid” model. Rather remote participants gathered in a central site local to them and were supported by a facilitator from our team. Each day, the remote participants gathered face-to-face to live stream the peripheral participation portions of the professional development, sharing their thinking and questions through a moderated chat function on the streaming platform, then engaged in a live discussion-leading professional development session facilitated in-person by a facilitator from our team. 


We focus on mathematics discussions because they are rich sites for supporting students’ collective learning of mathematics and challenging for classroom teachers to facilitate. They are central to standards for both teaching practice and student engagement with mathematics, though modal teaching practice often does not include discussion-leading. 


This project examined the impact of the professional development on teachers’ mathematics discussion-leading practice across multiple variations designed to make professional development scalable, including online streaming participation and local site-based facilitated streaming. A tool for examining specific discussion-leading moves was used to measure changes in teachers’ practice as observed through submitted video recordings of mathematics discussions. Participants included 78 teachers from multiple school districts across the US who submitted a total of 469 videos across the study. The findings reveal that participation in professional development had a differential impact on participating groups. We explored group attributes, including the quality of discussions and general mathematics instruction prior to the professional development, teachers’ mathematical knowledge for teaching, and the specific moves that teachers were using prior to the professional development that could contribute to these differential outcomes. We also explored differences in the instruction observed during professional development as a potential factor in teachers’ learning opportunities. We found that while mathematical knowledge for teaching mattered for teacher learning, the teacher groups with the greatest instructional change were those that demonstrated modal teaching quality (as measured by the Mathematical Quality of Instruction tool) paired with infrequent high-quality discussions prior to professional development. This finding can help the field to better tailor professional development to meet the needs of teachers.


The project contributes to the field in several ways. First, the materials and ideas resulting from this project contribute to centering the content and delivery of professional education more squarely on teachers’ actual practice. Second, the findings suggesting that teachers benefited both from in-person and remote participation address the challenge of scalability. Third, the findings provide the field with initial findings about how the resources that teachers bring contribute to their learning. Lastly, for those teachers participating in this study, enhanced capabilities with leading discussions led to improved learning experiences for their students.
